Article Title: After the post goes viral, Google engineer says: The most-divisive subject for software engineers today is ...
Article Text:
AI generated image for representation

Coding Agents have divided developers across the spectrum



How good or bad is the quality of code AI can generate

Complimenting a competitor





A Google principal engineer named Jaaana Dogan has almost gone 'viral' along with her post on how AI has transformed coding in the last one year. In a post on X, formerly Twitter, Dogan wrote, "I'm not joking and this isn't funny. We have been trying to build distributed agent orchestrators at Google since last year. There are various options, not everyone is aligned... I gave Claude Code a description of the problem, it generated what we built last year in an hour." The post that has so far received almost 7 million views has triggered a debate on the role of AI tools like Claude, Google Gemini and others in software coding, with advocates on both sides.Soon after her post on using Claude Code for coding went viral, Dogan clarified that the code generated is not perfect but a good start. "It's not perfect and I'm iterating on it but this is where we are right now. If you are skeptical of coding agents, try it on a domain you are already an expert of. Build something complex from scratch where you can be the judge of the artifacts," she wrote. Talking of Vibe Coding, and how it existed in some form earlier too, she wrote, "The idea of everyone building software intimidates people.For me, growing up in the 80s and early 90s was unique because we used to program our own personal computers. Programming was an activity for everyone who had a computer."Dogan lamented that Coding Agents have divided the developer community and that she has never seen a trend that has been as divisive. "Since working on programming languages, I haven't seen this kind of polarized response from the developer community. There is a ton of hype & fluff about coding agents, which unfortunately often drowns out the genuinely good work being done. Things don't have to be this divisive." She added in another after a series of posts on the topic, "Coding agents are the most divisive subject. There are people who genuinely want to learn, there are skeptics, and there are people who are so dogmatic that they want to remove all sorts of communication on this subject. 2026 will be an interesting year."Dogan said that the developer community has always been divided in camps, and went on to describe three. She wrote: "The developer community has always been divided into a few camps:- People who are open to new modern tools- People who are building tools with new modern toolsand- People who think you should lose your job for using any modern tools."When prompted on the quality of the code generated by Claude, Dogan said, "To cut through the noise on this topic, it’s helpful to provide more more context:- We have built several versions of this system last year. - There are tradeoffs and there hasn't been a clear winner.- When prompted with the best ideas that survived, coding agents are able to go very far and generate a good decent toy version in an hour or so."The Google engineer called all the controversy around Coding Agents on layoffs. "All the controversy around coding agents is just a symptom. Where we are as an industry and the state of the job market is the main issue here since the beginning," she said.When asked about using a competitor's tool, Dogan said, "This industry has never been a zero-sum game, so it’s easy to give credit where it’s due even when it's a competitor. Claude Code is impressive work, I'm excited and more motivated to push us all forward."
Article Summary: Google engineer Jaaana Dogan has almost gone 'viral' along with her post on how AI has transformed coding in the last one year. The post that has so far received almost 7 million views has triggered a debate on the role of AI tools like Claude, Google Gemini and others in software coding.

Article Title: Ashley St Clair alleges Elon Musk’s Grok ‘undressed’ her childhood images; sparking AI safety concerns

Ashley St Clair’s claims against Elon Musk’s AI tool Grok

Govt Sends Notice To Elon Musk's X On Grok AI Chatbot Misuse, IT Ministry Seeks Action Report

Source: X

Source: X

Widespread misuse of Grok’s image-manipulation features

What sparked the Grok digital undressing backlash





Ashley St Clair has accused Elon Musk ’s AI chatbot Grok of generating sexually suggestive edits of her photographs without consent, including images taken when she was only 14 years old. The allegations have surfaced amid growing concern over Grok’s ability to digitally alter images on X in response to explicit user prompts. St Clair, a columnist who previously made headlines after claiming she shares a child with Musk, says the incident represents a serious breach of consent, safety, and child protection laws. Her public statements have intensified scrutiny on xAI and its safeguards, while also reopening wider debates around AI misuse, accountability, and the risks faced by women and minors on large social media platforms.Ashley St Clair asserts that she found that Grok had reproduced modified pictures of her despite assurances that this chatbot would not create non-consensual pictures. On X, she began writing a series of messages where she accused Grok of sharing such pictures despite her objections. She demanded that this chatbot remove the posts and identification details that would be needed in case of legal proceedings against xAI.The most problematic part of the allegation from St Clair is the imagery that she was 14 at the time it was produced. Grok generated a bikini picture in response to an instruction from a user.The original picture was a child's image that had been transformed. According to a media article quoting the now-deleted Facebook account of the alleged victim, Grok was accused by the victim of making things that might make them uncomfortable in the future. Despite the imagery not involving full nudity, the alleged victim expressed the desire for it to be deleted.St Clair was quite expressive when she condemned the incident, with Grok’s actions described as ‘horrifying’ and ‘illegal’ by the Instagram spokesperson. These are mostly young females, although there are also requests for males, public figures, and pets, highlighting systemic safeguards gaps, ethical risks, and urgent regulatory oversight.X has been inundated by images of women displayed in minimal clothing and/or changed clothing, all produced by the use of AI images. These images primarily followed the activation of Grok to "undress" women and display them in bikinis. The chatbot was known to have responded to a vast array of these requests, thereby editing the images of women into sexually explicit images of themselves without their consent. However, looking at the situation in its entirety, there is a growing need for greater control over the use of generative AI technology, putting pressure once again on Elon Musk and his ventures to be accountable.

Article Title: Ten technology trends to watch in 2026
Article Text:
After years of AI hype, 2026 brings a reality check. Companies need to prove their billion-dollar bets are worth it. Data centres are spreading globally, straining power grids. AI agents are moving from pilots to production. Robots are getting smarter. New hardware forms are arriving. Meanwhile, tech billionaires keep getting richer. The gap between hype and deployment is shrinking fast, and 2026 could turn out to be a real pivoting year.

AI shifts from hype to payback

Data centres spread across the globe

Work gets reimagined

Hardware gets weird new forms

Computing gets smarter, not just bigger

New models go beyond text

Robots become real(er)

The startup birth rate soars

Tech billionaires get even richer

What the 2026 really looks like





After years of AI hype and billion-dollar bets, 2026 is shaping up to be a reality check for the tech industry. Companies that dumped money into generative AI tools now face a simple question: show us the value, or shut it down.The pace of change isn't slowing. If anything, it's getting faster. Tools that seemed cutting-edge six months ago already feel outdated. Companies are racing to stay ahead, while also trying to prove their investments weren't wasted.Here are the ten trends in technology to watch out for in 2026.The experimental phase is over. Enterprises spent 2024 and 2025 testing AI pilots and proof-of-concept projects. Now they want measurable returns on those investments."2026 is the 'show me the money' year for AI," says Venky Ganesan, a partner at Menlo Ventures. Companies will demand hard ROI numbers. Those that can't deliver value will see their software renewals drop and their fundraising dry up.This pressure will split the market. Some AI companies will thrive by solving specific problems well. Others will struggle or fail entirely. Ganesan predicts at least one major AI company will face severe financial trouble or bankruptcy in 2026.The flip side: successful companies could go public. Both OpenAI and SpaceX are eyeing IPOs at valuations near $1 trillion. If these launches succeed, they'll create a wave of new wealth and validate AI's business potential.You heard a lot about data centres in 2025. Get ready to hear more in 2026.The infrastructure boom that started in the US and China is going global. India is attracting massive investment from tech giants. Microsoft committed $17.5 billion to new data centres there. Before Microsoft's CEO left the stage at that announcement, Amazon declared it would spend $35 billion on its own facilities. Google and Meta quickly followed with their own multi-billion dollar plans.Southeast Asia is seeing double-digit growth in data centre capacity. Brazil wants to become Latin America's hub. Saudi Arabia and the UAE struck $600 billion in AI deals with the US, including plans for the largest AI campus outside America.This expansion creates real problems. These facilities consume enormous amounts of electricity and water. In hot regions, cooling requirements push consumption even higher. Brazil has already seen blackouts tied to data centre demand. Local communities often can't find out how much power and water a facility will use, thanks to legal secrecy.China offers a warning: just because you build it doesn't mean they'll come. The country rushed to construct about 150 new data centres in 2024. Now up to 80% of that new computing capacity sits unused, struggling to find customers.AI hasn't replaced most workers yet. Even though it has impacted a big number of workers, changing how work gets done in particular niches.Coding looks completely different than it did five years ago. Developers use AI assistants that can generate, debug, and refactor code. The technology has matured enough that these tools genuinely save time. Customer service is being handed over to chatbots, despite customer frustration.AI agents were the buzzword of 2025, but most stayed in pilot programs. Only 11% of organisations actually deployed them in production, despite 38% running tests. The gap between pilot and production tells the real story. Many companies automated broken processes instead of redesigning their operations from scratch. That approach rarely works.In 2026, agents will become more capable and trustworthy. They'll handle complex, multi-step tasks without constant human oversight. Think booking entire trips, negotiating better service rates, or managing workflows across different systems. "A year from now, answering questions will be the least useful thing AI can do," says Fidji Simo, OpenAI's CEO of applications. "We'll have proactive AI assistants constantly running in the background, getting things done for us. "But there's a catch. Many companies will spin out hundreds of agents per employee, only to see most sit idle. Without proper integration into existing workflows, these agents become expensive shelfware. The winners will be companies that connect agents to deterministic systems and give them clear, focused tasks.The smartphone has looked basically the same for a decade: a big black screen with some buttons on the side. That's changing.Apple is rumoured to release a folding phone in 2026. Android devices have already gone this route, even including some phones that fold twice. But Apple's loyal customer base could make folding screens mainstream.Then, a lot of others are also racing to build the first successful AI hardware device. OpenAI invested $6.5 billion in Jony Ive's startup, which is working on a physical AI product. The Humane pin and Friend necklace both made noise but never caught on. Humane has already shut down.Smart glasses present the most promising direction. They're already popular, and Meta dominates the space. In 2026, expect these devices to get smarter and more common. They offer a natural way to interact with AI without pulling out your phone.You'll also see AI show up in places you didn't ask for it. Samsung already added its Bixby assistant to refrigerators back in 2024. Hotels might offer smart duvets. Your rental car might have an AI assistant. Not all of this will be useful or wanted.The AI infrastructure race is shifting from raw scale to efficiency. You can't keep throwing more computing power at every problem."2026 will be the year of frontier versus efficient model classes," says Kaoutar El Maghraoui, a principal research scientist at IBM. Next to huge models with billions of parameters, you'll see efficient, hardware-aware models running on modest accelerators.The hardware race won't only be about GPUs anymore. ASICs, chiplet designs, analogue inference, and quantum-assisted optimisers will all mature. A new class of chips designed specifically for running AI agents could emerge.Think of it like air traffic control for AI workloads. Computing power will be packed more densely and routed dynamically. If one job slows, another moves in instantly. Nothing sits idle. This makes infrastructure smarter, more sustainable, and more adaptable.Quantum computing is also reaching an inflection point. Microsoft, Google, and others believe quantum machines will start tackling problems that classical computers can't handle. Hybrid systems that combine quantum, AI, and supercomputers could drive breakthroughs in materials science, drug development, and climate modelling.Large language models dominated AI development for the past few years. They predict the next word in a sequence. In 2026, a different approach could take centre stage: world models.World models work by learning from videos, simulations, and spatial inputs. Instead of predicting the next word, they predict what happens next in the physical world. They model how things move over time.This matters for robotics, video games, and any application where AI needs to understand cause and effect without being explicitly programmed. World models can grasp concepts like gravity or momentum just by watching.Google, Meta, and Chinese companies like Tencent are all developing world models. Yann LeCun, one of AI's pioneers, left Meta to launch a world model startup. Fei-Fei Li's company World Labs released its first model in 2025.At the same time, Europe is moving in a different direction: small language models. These are lightweight versions of LLMs designed to run on smartphones or low-powered computers. They use fewer parameters and consume less energy, but they can still handle text generation, translation, and question-answering.Small models make economic sense amid talk of the AI bubble bursting. They cost less to build, less to run, and don't require massive data centres. European governments are increasingly wary of depending on American AI infrastructure, which could accelerate investment in smaller, more sustainable models.AI security becomes mission-criticalAI creates a cybersecurity paradox: the same capabilities driving business innovation are also introducing new risks. In 2026, organisations will face mounting pressure to secure AI systems while defending against AI-powered attacks.The threats are multiplying fast. Shadow AI deployments bypass security controls. Adversarial attacks manipulate models into producing wrong outputs. AI agents operating with broad system access create new attack surfaces. "Every agent should have similar security protections as humans," says Vasu Jakkal, corporate vice president of Microsoft Security.Even OpenAI is sounding the alarm. CEO Sam Altman recently acknowledged that AI models are "starting to present some real challenges," including models that are "so good at computer security they are beginning to find critical vulnerabilities." The company is actively hiring a new Head of Preparedness to study emerging AI-related risks, from cybersecurity threats to mental health impacts. The role comes with a $555,000 salary, reflecting how seriously the company takes these challenges.Companies will need to secure four domains: data, models, applications, and infrastructure. Defenders are fighting back with AI agents for red teaming, adversarial training, and automated threat detection at machine speed.Robots are nothing like what they used to be. From pre-programmed machines, they are evolving into adaptive systems capable of perception, learning, and autonomous operation. Physical AI is breaking out of warehouses and into mainstream use.Amazon has already deployed its millionth robot, and if the company is to be believed, AI coordinates entire fleets, and that’s helping them save travel time by about 10%. At BMW plants, cars now drive themselves along production routes. The real magic, however, is when world models combine with robotics, allowing systems to comprehend their surroundings and adapt to surprises.The next frontier is humanoid robots that can navigate spaces designed for humans, as companies race to craft machines capable of doing just that. The potential stretches across manufacturing, healthcare, and disaster response, and is increasingly accessible beyond the early adopters as costs fall.AI coding tools are making it easier than ever to build software. The result: a wave of new startups hitting the market in 2026.Tools like Replit, Cursor, and Loveable let people build products without engineering backgrounds. You can go from idea to working software faster than ever before. Building AI agents is also getting simpler. Business users can create them without touching code.Not every startup will make it. Markets will get crowded. Competition will heat up. But the sheer number of new companies will reshape the landscape and push established players to move faster.Tech's wealthiest executives are about to get a lot wealthier. Ten top earners added $550 billion to their fortunes in 2025. The trend isn't slowing down.Two massive IPOs are coming: OpenAI and SpaceX, both valued near $1 trillion. SpaceX's debut will add tens of billions to Elon Musk's net worth, which already sits around $600 billion. He's also eligible for two Tesla pay packages worth a combined $1.056 trillion. Sam Altman stands to benefit from OpenAI's listing, along with major backers like Microsoft. Jeff Bezos Mark Zuckerberg , and Satya Nadella have all seen their wealth climb as AI investments pay off.Larry Ellison might be the exception. Oracle's stock dropped hard as investors questioned AI spending, erasing $80 billion in market value.Every trend in tech seems to point in one direction: more wealth flowing upward. The AI boom, the data centre buildout, the chip shortage, the agent revolution—all of it concentrates power and money in fewer hands. A handful of tech executives now wield enormous influence over technology that affects everyone's daily life.Every trend here points to the same reality: the distance between hype and deployment is collapsing. Tech used to take years to move from labs to living rooms. Now it takes months, sometimes weeks.This creates winners and losers fast. Companies that can't prove AI's value will fold. Workers in certain fields will find their jobs radically different or gone entirely. Cities welcoming data centres might face power shortages they didn't plan for. Meanwhile, a small group of tech billionaires keeps getting richer off all of it, concentrating more control over systems that affect billions of people.The pace isn't slowing down. If anything, 2026 will be the year when that becomes impossible to ignore.
